title: WMO annual report highlights continuous advance of climate change

last_post.content:
The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) report on the State of the Global Climate in 2022 was released today:

"...shows the planetary scale changes on land, in the ocean and in the atmosphere caused by record levels of heat-trapping greenhouse gases"

https://public.wmo.int/en/media/press-release/wmo-annual-report-highlights-continuous-advance-of-climate-change

Today is #EarthDay 🌍!

We celebrate our planet with ambitious measures to overcome #climate change and environmental degradation.

We are working hard to transform our Union into the first climate-neutral continent by 2050! How?

With:

✅ environmentally-friendly technologies

✅ cleaner, cheaper and healthier forms of #transport

✅ decarbonisation of the #energy sector

✅ more energy-efficient buildings

✅ support to industry innovation

More about the #EUGreenDeal → https://europa.eu/!8bB4bR

Today the WMO released its State of the Global Climate 2022 report. Thirty years of satellite-based measurements show an acceleration of global mean sea-level (GMSL) rise, from 2.3 mm/yr over the 1993-2002 decade to 3.3 mm/yr over the 2003-2012 decade and then to 4.6 mm/yr over the 2013-2022 decade. More frequent episodes of coastal flooding and erosion are expected in most places around the world.

Report download: https://library.wmo.int/index.php?lvl=notice_display&id=22265

#sealevel #sealevelrise #globalwarming #climatechange

title: What It’s Like To Stop Using Google Search - Debugger

last_post.content:
"What It's Like To Stop Using Google Search"

Most of the time I don't notice a thing ...

... because a surprisingly large fraction of my searches are navigational ("where's the site for that *thing* again?") or informational at a level that's trivially easy for any search service at all

So the actual cost of switching is ... pretty low

(DuckDuckGo's my main search these days)

My essay on it: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551

A little app for drawing graphs

https://git.sr.ht/~akkartik/snap.love

I've wanted something like this for a long time. Intended for small graphs where laying things out by hand is not too painful, and it's nice that things don't move around every time I make a change, as happens with graphviz (https://graphviz.org). The file format is also amenable to git; no long lines, and adding new nodes or edges doesn't reorder unrelated nodes and edges.
